text:
Hi there. As a child I always use to hear
jokes about people, who cannot pronounce the

“P” and the “B” correctly. Let me
share you a joke. How will someone, who does

not know the difference between the P and
the B cross the road? The answer is symboly.

Those who understood the joke keep smiling
and those who did not; I will explain this

to you later. Hi my name is Emmelda and today
I will be discussing the difference between

the “P” and the “B”. When I was in
Spain, I met a guy through a common friend

and it was in a get-together, so after a while
as a night too drunk up, he said lets go to

Baba Jones. I thought Oh! Probably it’s
a copy of the famous chain of restaurants

called the Papa Jones. So we drove along and
I finally understood that he actually meant

Papa Jones. So I asked him in a conversation,
I asked him so what’s up with the “P”

and the “B” and he said you see Emmelda
in our language we don’t have a different

P or B, because the mouth movement is the
same, P, B same, that got in trigging and

I was thinking, so what is the difference
between “P” and the “B” and how would

you explain it to someone? Did my research
and then revelation. Let’s get started with

the basic sound “B” is a voice sound.
What do you mean by voice? Touch your throat

and while you say “B”, B, you hear a vibration
here B, however “P” is an unvoiced consonant.

For example, it says P. When we say P there’s
so much gush of air from your mouth. You actually

build up air in your mouth, when you close
it. P, take a look at this. Keep your hand

in front of your mouth “P”, you’ll feel
the air rushing through your fingers “P”,

“B”, you don’t feel the air P, B. So
there is slight rather a very prominent difference

between P and the B. Now let’s see how these
two alphabets when they come in different

words, how are they pronounced? The first
word we have is Bat as in bat, so its bat,

however if you use, if you replace this with
P it becomes Pat, as in your patting the board

or patting yourself, so its bat, pat repeat
one more time, bat, pat. B, so it’s B. If

you could feel the vibration B. The B and
the P, the funny part is you keep your mouth

as if you’re smiling B, P. So its B, feel
the vibration P, feel the air, P, B, no air

but there’s vibration, bin, bin,bin. This
one pin, pin, you will feel the air, but no

vibration, pin, bin, born as in a baby is
born or you’re born on a particular date,

so its born, porn. My dear guy friends please,
I’m just talking about the sounds, don’t

think weird or don’t think stupid. It’s
just porn. One is the adult movies that we

can watch for entertainment. The other one
is pawn for those who don’t know the meaning

of pawn, it is something that if you have
an item and you want money, you will just

give someone and exchange for money, but for
a short period of time. So its porn, pawn,

born. Bush as in President Bush, you know
the ex-president of United States, bush, bush,

push, push. You can’t say let me bush you,
it doesn’t really sound well, so its bush

and push. Abort, abort, now these are the
words I’m gonna talk about where the B comes

in the middle of the word, so its abort, abort.
Again no air but vibration, however look at

this apart, apart, you are actually closing
your mouth, trying to build the air ap, ap.

There’s no air in your mouth by now, but
when you say part the air comes out of your

mouth apart, apart. So its abort no air, abort
vibration, apart, apart, you still feel the

air, Cubical, cubical is a small room or a
small area which is covered and you really

don’t have a lot of space there, so its
cubical, cubical, couple, couple. You still

have the air, however compared to the words
which you begin with this has lesser air.

Couple, cubical and couple are spelt like
this, sorry pronounced like this, its “Q”,

it’s not seubical, its cubical, couple,
couple, fumble. Fumble is when you’re not

sure and you start stammering, you start doing
mistake or you’re fumbling. So its fumble

specially this happens specially if you are
going for an interview and you are not sure

what to say, so you start fumbling. Flapper,
flapper is a flat board through which you

keep patting. For example, if you are swimming,
you have those flapper shoes when you are

swimming, you flap your legs. So Its flapper,
flapper, habit, habit. The air is in the beginning

of the word habit. You don’t say habet or
habith, it’s not habith, habit. Happy, now

notice this, here and here there is no air
habit, no air, happy, you don’t really have

that air, when you’re talking happy. So
there are certain areas, where you have to

be little conscious of how are you pronouncing
the word. You don’t say happie, it’s not

happie, but happy, happy. I am very happy
for you, I hope you’re happy now, happy.

The next is the animal Zebra, zebra. Here
since there are two consonants, even before

you could finish the B, you already start
the R sound, zebra, zebra, zipper, zipper,

zipper again same as the happy, probably it’s
a coincidence. I’m not, I cannot say it’s

a rule that the moment you have two “P’s
there is no air, no it’s not like that,

English has lot of rules, but it has lot of
exceptions as well. So it’s happy, zipper,

zebra. We have the next as Cub, cub, cup as
in a tea cup, dab, dab means when you take

a towel and dab yourself dry, dab, these words
are, if you notice the B comes at the end,

so we’ll try to understand how B is pronounced
or P is pronounced, when it comes at the end.

Cup, cub, cup. Again there is hardly any air
here cup, cup, cub, cup, dab, dip, lab, lap,

lap. The last one that we have is mob, mob,
mop. The only thing that you have to understand

is the moment you have words which end with
P and if that word is followed by other few

words or especially the ones which start with
avowel, you don’t aspirate it or you don’t

bring so much air, you don’t say I have
cupatty, you don’t say cupatty. May I have

a cupatty or may I have a cup of tea, so there
is not so much air. Now coming back to my

joke, which I was sharing at the beginning
of the video is basically the person says,

he actually just wanted to cross the road
simply, but because he does not know the meaning.

Probably now he is going to cross the road
symboly, basically he will be looking at the

symbols and then cross the road, so that’s
the funny joke. A lot of people don’t get

it at the first time; it’s only those who
are quite aware of the difference between

P and the B, they will get at the first time.
So I hope you enjoyed my lesson, I will be

coming back with new lessons. Until I come
back stay healthy, be beautiful and have fun
learning English.
